content:
The "Violence Against Children Act of 2003" may be cited as such. Congress finds that children under 18 account for a significant portion of crime victims, with high rates of sex crimes and kidnapping. They are also more likely to be victims of violent crime compared to adults. Many crimes against children go unreported, leading to long-lasting negative effects such as delayed development and substance abuse. Lack of resources hinders local agencies from adequately protecting children and families in need. Failure to pay child support is considered a form of neglect. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families in need, leading to issues like inadequate education, healthcare, and housing for neglected children. Failure to pay child support contributes to children living in poverty. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Title I of the United States Code is amended to include enhanced penalties for violence against children, with imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines for injuring a person under 18. More severe penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The circumstances include the offense occurring during travel of the defendant or victim. The amended Title I of the United States Code imposes enhanced penalties for violence against children, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines for injuring a person under 18. More severe penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, sexual abuse, or attempted murder, with specific circumstances outlined for when the offense occurs during travel across state lines or using interstate commerce. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for federal crimes against children under 18. The Comptroller General will review state laws on crimes against children and report findings to Congress. Additionally, there will be enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. SEC. 102 of the bill provides enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General will offer technical, forensic, and prosecutorial support for crimes of violence or felonies committed against individuals under 18 years old. Priority will be given to crimes involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states and rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges in investigating or prosecuting the crime. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, technical assistance, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. This includes training for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and developing units specifically targeting crimes against children, as well as implementing effective policies and services for preventing and responding to such crimes. The grant program focuses on preventing, identifying, and responding to crimes against children by developing effective police and prosecution policies, enhancing cross-collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with such crimes. The grant program aims to address crimes against children by developing effective policies, enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and supporting Indian tribes in dealing with such crimes. States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments seeking a grant must submit an application outlining the grant's purpose, intended use of funds, and expected outcomes. The grant applicants must demonstrate consultation with victim services programs and certify that federal funds will supplement non-federal funds without supplanting them. Compliance with regulations is also required. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 to carry out the activities funded under this section, provided that federal funds supplement non-federal funds without supplanting them and compliance with regulations is met. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, and counseling for victims and their families. The grants awarded by the Attorney General aim to prevent crimes against children, increase awareness in minority communities, provide emergency medical treatment, counseling for victims and families, and enhance mental health support for victims. States, tribal governments, local governments, or organizations seeking grants must submit applications detailing the grant's purpose. Applicants for grants under this section must describe the grant's purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. They also need to show consultation with victim services programs experienced in helping children who are victims of crimes. Applicants for grants under this section must consult with victim services programs experienced in helping children who are victims of crimes and certify that federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for these activities. Applicants for grants under this section must certify that federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for activities and comply with section 303. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2004 through 2008. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn baby with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history, search missing person databases, and publicize the State's Safe Haven law. Exceptions apply if the baby shows signs of abuse. The State's Safe Haven law includes a plan for publicizing it. An exception allows a State statute to deny a parent the ability to leave a newborn baby anonymously if signs of abuse are present. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. States receiving funding for child welfare services must submit a report on their programs within 180 days. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices and policies, including record-keeping and well-being verification for children in care. The report will assess the effectiveness of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services in reforming child welfare systems. The curr_chunk discusses how States are maintaining records and verifying the well-being of children in their care, the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, best practices implemented by States, and recommendations for legislative changes by Congress. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment on bad debt to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for unpaid child support and requiring unpaid amounts to be added to income for tax purposes.
